snippet: New York City has bought millions of “super stacker” classroom chairs since the 1990s, but districts around the country are choosing models deemed ergonomically superior.
abstract: New York City public schools have continued to buy millions of familiar, durable 'super stacker' chairs, even as other districts around the country have turned to ergonomic alternatives; cost of conversion could be extremely high, though schools chancellor Dennis M Walcott remains open to change.

byline.contributor: Alain Delaquérière and Sheelagh McNeill contributed research.

lead_paragraph: New York City has bought millions of “super stacker” classroom chairs since the 1990s, but districts around the country are choosing models deemed ergonomically superior.
